div.p: Expansão efectuada internamente com base em codesystem Lifestyle Medicine Observation Codes v0.1.0 (CodeSystem)
Este conjunto de valores contém 62 conceitos

tr.td: Panel for comprehensive sleep measurements including duration, stages, and quality metrics

td.i: (Sleep measurement panel from consumer devices maps to broader LOINC Polysomnography panel. Source is more specific (consumer device panel) than target (clinical polysomnography). LOINC 90568-7 contains terms from American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) guidelines. Consumer devices measure subset of clinical polysomnography parameters.)
(Alternative mapping to general wearable device panel. Target is less specific (covers all wearable physiologic monitoring) than source (sleep-specific panel).)

tr.td: Average environmental noise level measured in decibels (dB) over a specified time period
Duration of exposure to environmental noise above a threshold level
Maximum (peak) environmental sound level measured during a monitoring period
Baseline or background environmental noise level measured in quiet conditions
Duration of deep (slow-wave) sleep stage as measured by consumer sleep tracking device
Duration of light sleep stage as measured by consumer sleep tracking device
Count of awakenings or sleep interruptions during a sleep period

td.i: (Sleep awakenings count is related to but distinct from 'Wake time after sleep onset' (LOINC 103215-0). Source measures NUMBER of awakenings (discrete count), target measures DURATION of wakefulness after initial sleep onset (time in minutes). Both concepts assess sleep fragmentation but from different perspectives. No exact LOINC match for awakening count exists as of November 2025.)

tr.td: Total time spent in bed, including time awake before and after sleep
Total duration of social interactions or time spent in social activities
Subjective quality rating of social interactions
Method or medium of social interaction (in-person, phone, video, text, etc.)
Count of distinct social interactions or social contacts during a time period
Physiological markers or indicators of stress response (e.g., heart rate variability, cortisol)
Self-reported psychological stress level or score from validated assessment
Assessment of stress duration and persistence (acute vs. chronic stress)
Assessment of the impact or severity of stress on daily functioning and health
Ultraviolet radiation index measurement indicating sun exposure intensity
Duration of exposure to ultraviolet radiation
Duration of time exposed to a specific environmental condition
Heart rate variability measurement in specific frequency band (LF, HF, VLF)
Entropy measurement of heart rate variability indicating complexity
Analysis of arterial pulse wave characteristics
Variability in respiratory rate over time
Calculated index of blood oxygenation efficiency
Composite index of physiological stress markers
Index measuring balance between sympathetic and parasympathetic activity
Index measuring rate of physiological recovery after activity
Measure of cumulative physiological burden and wear-and-tear on the body from chronic stress
Quantitative score from balance assessment test
Qualitative status of balance (normal, impaired, etc.)
Assessment of walking pattern and gait characteristics
General movement quality and mobility assessment
Total calories consumed in a specified time period
Panel for comprehensive macronutrient intake measurements
Status of ovulation as measured by consumer fertility tracking device
Device for monitoring and tracking sleep patterns and sleep quality metrics
Device for monitoring environmental conditions such as noise, temperature, humidity, and UV exposure
Panel for comprehensive body composition measurements from bioimpedance analysis
A session of mindfulness meditation or practice including breathing exercises, body scans, or mindful awareness
Subjective observation of the relaxation response experienced during or after mindfulness or relaxation practice
The specific type or technique of mindfulness or meditation practice performed
Daily water consumption measured in liters or milliliters
Measurement of walking speed during ambulation
Measurement of walking balance and steadiness
Heart rate measurement during physical exercise activity
Type of alcoholic beverage consumed (beer, wine, spirits, etc.)
Source of dietary caffeine intake (coffee, tea, energy drinks, etc.)
Date and time of the most recent caffeine consumption
How often a substance is used (daily, weekly, monthly, etc.)
Date when a substance was last used
Comprehensive summary of all substance use patterns for lifestyle medicine assessment
Aggregate risk assessment based on all substance use patterns

Assessment of the correlation between heart rate variability metrics (especially RMSSD) and inflammatory biomarkers (CRP, IL-6). Based on RS1 systematic review finding: inverse correlation between vagal tone and systemic inflammation via cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway (Tracey 2002).

div.p: Expansão efectuada internamente com base em:

li.a: codesystem ISO 21089 2017 Health Record Lifecycle Events v1.0.0 (CodeSystem)

div.p: Este conjunto de valores contém 7 conceitos

tr.td: Fundamental operation in an Information System (IS) that results only in the act of bringing an object into existence. Note: The preceding definition is taken from the HL7 RBAC specification. There is no restriction on how the operation is invoked, e.g., via a user interface. For an HL7 Act, the state transitions per the HL7 Reference Information Model.

Fundamental operation in an Information System (IS) that results only in the revision or alteration of an object. Note: The preceding definition is taken from the HL7 RBAC specification. There is no restriction on how the operation is invoked, e.g., via a user interface.

Fundamental operation in an Information System (IS) that results only in the addition of information to an object already in existence. Note: The preceding definition is taken from the HL7 RBAC specification. There is no restriction on how the operation is invoked, e.g., via a user interface.
Occurs when an agent causes the system to: a) initiate capture of potential record content, and b) incorporate that content into the storage considered a permanent part of the health record.
Occurs when an agent causes the system to change the form, language or code system used to represent record entry content.
Occurs when an agent causes the system to send record entry content from one (EHR/PHR/other) system to another.
Occurs when an agent causes the system to a) initiate capture of data content from elsewhere, and b) incorporate that content into the storage considered a permanent part of the health record.
